title: are all painting companies the same in kansas City, MO?
expand: No, not all painting companies are the same in Kansas City. On a major project like new exterior paint, interview several local professional painters and make sure you are present when they come to estimate your project. Look for attention to detail, ask about their painting process and ask if you can drive by some of their other jobs to see their work, and always check out the credentials (insurance, online reviews, website, warranty, etc…).

title: how long does a house painting project take?
expand:
On average homes we paint take 3.5 days. Small, 1 level homes can be quicker and take 2, depending on the condition they’re in. Large multi level homes with lots of trim and prep work (such as those in Westport or Brookside) can take 1 to 2 weeks.

The time it will take to finish the job will depend on the condition your home is in, your expectations and needs, and the size of your house. Our estimator will be able to give you a good approximation of the time it will take to paint your home after meeting with you.

title: do you spray, spray and backroll, or brush and roll the paint?
expand:
It depends on the surface we’re painting.

Over the last several years, we’ve not performed any brush and roll only jobs. Brush and roll only takes considerably longer and is therefore considerably more expensive. If you are thinking you’d like brush and roll only, talk to you estimator about why and we can always price it as an option for you.

Spray and backroll is necessary when the surface is porous (like an open grained wood) or dry (like stucco being painted for the first time). In order to provide a uniform finish that looks great, the paint needs to be pushed down into the pores. During your walkaround with your estimator, we’ll walk you through our painting process and point out where we’d recommend the surface be sprayed and backrolled and get your feedback or answer questions you might have.

Sprayers themselves haven’t changed much in the last 10 years but the tips they use have. Tips are now excellent at atomizing the paint (making a very fine mist) and delivering the paint to the painted surface reliably. We use Graco paint sprayers and they are high-tech, very expensive machines specifically designed to do what we’re doing as professional painters. Spraying produces the nicest looking finish, the most uniform coating, and when used by a professional painter gives the customer the highest quality product most efficiently. In the hands of an experienced paint crew, 1 pass with a sprayer over a properly prepared surface will produce a better coating than multiple passes with a brush and roller.
